STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
January 21, 2021
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2021C0112012
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2021C0112012

Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504-1487

Administrator: Kathleen Schultz
Licensee Designee: Sean De Four, Designee
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Facility Address: 1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072

Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Since 2018, agency staff members are not exploring/utilizing Yes
relative placement regarding a foster care case.
III. METHODOLOGY
12/17/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0112012
12/17/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Phone call with Chief Administrator
12/29/2020 Contact - Document Sent
Email sent to assigned foster care worker
12/29/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone interview with assigned foster care worker
12/29/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
ATC to foster care supervisor
12/29/2020 Contact - Document Sent
Email sent to foster care supervisor/previously assigned foster
care worker
01/05/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email sent to foster care supervisor
01/05/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from FC Supervisor, scheduled phone interview for 1/7/21
01/07/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed Supervisor 1
01/07/2021 Contact - Document Received
Text received from relative
01/07/2021 Contact - Telephone call received
Call received from relative during which we discussed my findings
01/08/2021 Contact - Document Received
Text received from relative
2

01/08/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
Since 2018, agency staff members are not exploring/utilizing relative placement
regarding a foster care case.
INVESTIGATION:
On 12/10/2020 and 12/28/2020 I reviewed the youth and provider case records in
MiSACWIS. The files indicate that the youth were placed in foster care on
4/29/2018. The following documentation related to Relative A was reviewed:
 8/26/2019 – Central Registry form completed
 11/26/2019 – Social Work contact, Relative A called the worker who was
assigned the case at that time “screaming” and asking why she wasn’t called to
take placement of the children.
 11/26/2019 - The worker mailed a central registry clearance request for Relative
A to fill out.
 12/3/2019 – Criminal history clearances were completed
 12/10/2019 and 12/16/2019 – Messages were left for Relative A
 12/23/2019 – Relative A began visits with the youth.
 1/17/2020- Relative A left a voicemail message for the worker stating she wanted
to adopt the children.
 1/15/2020 an email request to Relative A for write ups regarding her criminal
history
 1/15/2020 - An internal relative referral form to licensing was completed by the
worker
 1/16/2020 – Written document by Relative A addressing criminal history
 1/22/2020 – Signed consent for release of DHHS records
 1/28/2020 – Criminal history/police reports from local police departments
 4/8/2020 – A Relative Placement Safety Screen (DHHS-5770) recommending
denial of placement
 5/19/2020 – Placement denial letter addressed to Relative A
On 12/29/2020 I interviewed Foster Care (FC) Worker 1 by phone. She reported that
she was assigned to the case at the beginning of 2020 and that Supervisor 1
previously had the case. She reported that when the case was transferred to her,
her supervisor told her that Relative A and other relatives did not express interest in
placement of the children until the case was heading toward termination of parental
rights. FC Worker 1 stated that Relative A has monthly visits with the children and is
currently working with a licensing worker and an adoption worker regarding potential
placement/adoption of the children.
3

On 12/30/2020 I interviewed Relative A by phone. She reported that when her
daughter went to jail in April of 2018, three of her children were with Relative A.
Relative A’s oldest daughter came to get the children after which Relative A received
a call from her daughter stating that the children were being removed from her home
and placed into foster care. Relative A stated that she previously had custody of two
of the children, so she believed the agency had her contact information, but she was
never contacted to take placement of the children. She stated that a worker came to
her work the Monday after the children were placed into foster care and took a copy
of Relative A’s ID and Social Security card. She stated that she never heard
anything from the worker regarding whether or not she was approved for placement,
so she called the agency multiple times. She reported that in May of 2018, a
different worker came to her home, completed a walk through and told her that her
home was sufficient for the children. When she again did not hear anything from the
agency regarding placement of the children, she called and spoke to Supervisor 1
who told her that the worker who came to her home should not have done a
walkthrough and should never have told her that her home was adequate. Relative A
stated that she never received any written documents related to that walkthrough
and has been fighting to get placement of the children since. She stated that she did
not get visitation with the children until December of 2019 and only gets to see them
once a month for supervised visits. She stated that she is now working with the
adoption and licensing departments to be considered for adoption of the children.
On 1/7/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 1 by phone. She reported that she is the
current supervisor on the case and had been assigned case management
responsibilities for a brief period in the final months of 2019 during worker transition
and when termination of the children’s parental rights was being requested. She
reported that, when she took over the case, one of the children’s paternal
grandfather was allowing Relative A to have visitation with the child during his
unsupervised visits. When Supervisor 1 found out about this, she made the
grandfather’s visits supervised after which Relative A contacted her to arrange her
own visitation in November of 2019. Relative A started having visits with the children
the following month but did not ask Supervisor 1 that she be considered for
placement of the children until January of 2020 at which point Supervisor 1 made a
referral to the licensing department for Relative A to be assessed. She stated that
she does not know if Relative A requested to be considered for placement of the
children prior to that, though she stated that the agency staff had Relative A’s
contact information throughout the case. Supervisor 1 reported that the first two
workers who were assigned the case are no longer working for the agency and were
both terminated due to issues related to their work performance, so she was not
surprised that they did not complete the required relative search and engagement
documentation. When asked if Relative A was assessed for placement at any time
prior to April of 2020, Supervisor 1 stated that Relative A did not reach out to the
agency to request placement until November of 2019 and she was not aware if any
of the assigned foster care workers reached out to Relative A to ask if she wanted to
be considered for placement.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-03 B RELATIVE ENGAGEMENT AND PLACEMENT
If a child must be removed from his/her home, preference must be
given to placement with a relative. Due diligence must be
exercised to identify and provide notice to all adult relatives that a
related child is in foster care. Ongoing efforts to identify, locate,
and engage relatives is an expected part of case planning and
permanency.
Relative Search Forms
DHS-991, Diligent Search Checklist- is a tool that must be used in
the search for relatives.
DHS-987, Relative Documentation- is a mandatory form used to
document the name, address, telephone number, results of
American Indian heritage inquiry, and relationship of every relative
identified. Caseworkers must document all relative search contacts
on the DHS-987, Relative Documentation.
Subsequent or Planned Placements
Caseworkers must complete a Relative Placement Safety Screen
for all adult relatives who express an interest in placement, within
five business days of the relative's written request for placement
consideration.
Denied Placement Recommendation
If the placement recommendation on the Relative Placement
Safety Screen is denied, then a DHS-31, Foster Care Placement
Decision Notice, is required to be provided to the relative with a
copy of the Safety Screen, within five business days of the
denial
5

ANALYSIS: There is no available documentation to indicate that due
diligence was exercised to assess Relative A for placement of her
grandchildren prior to them being placed in an unrelated foster
home or at any time throughout the case. There is no available
documentation to indicate that the agency made diligent efforts to
engage Relative A prior to Relative A requesting visitation with the
children, despite the agency staff having Relative A’s contact
information throughout the case.
The only available DHS-991 and DHS-987 forms did not include
Relative A’s information.
A Relative Placement Safety Screen was not completed timely as it
was finalized 4/8/2020 despite the assigned worker forwarding a
referral form to the licensing department on 1/15/2020.
There is no documentation indicating that a DHS-31, Foster Care
Placement Decision Notice was provided to the relative with a copy
of the Safety Screen. A letter of denial and a copy of the Relative
Placement Safety Screen was mailed to Relative A on 5/19/2020,
which is outside of the requirement to notify the relative within five
business days of the denial.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no change to the license of this child placing agency upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan.
January 8, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 12, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
